summary: Nicholas B. Stevenson was a Sergeant in the USAF. He was interviewed by the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) regarding allegations made by David F. Christensen concerning President Kennedy's assassination. The interview focused on Stevenson's recollections of events at USA-55, Kirknewton, Scotland, specifically concerning a facility able to collect the Lisbon-Tangier link. Following the interview, Julia Wetzel from the NSA reviewed the report and recommended portions be classified as "CONFIDENTIAL, HANDLE VIA COMINT CHANNELS ONLY" due to sensitive communications intelligence information.
significance: Nicholas B. Stevenson's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his interview with the HSCA regarding allegations related to possible Cuban involvement and his recollections of events at a communications facility in Scotland. The NSA's concern over the sensitivity of information revealed in the interview suggests that Stevenson may have had knowledge of communications intelligence relevant to the assassination.
